children.subject: It's more the size of the company!

Generally speaking you'll have a greater chance to have a higher impact at a smaller company, so if you would prefer that that's something to keep in mind. If you've worked at a large/small company in the past and would want to get a feel for what the other size of company is like to work at, then that's another way you can choose. The answer to your question also relies on what your career goals are. IMO if your goal is to work at FAANG as an SWE and you will be doing similar stuff at both companies I'd recommend going for the larger company. If you're more interested in working at startups then you might find the experience of interning at the smaller company more useful.
Thank you! It's FAANG vs smaller, so kinda just DK what my goal is I guess. I think I'm gonna go with smaller bc I'll have more of a chance to ship code and team placement is way less random

Oh yea the team placement is one annoying thing about larger companies to keep in mind. As someone who's interned at a large company (Nvidia AI Research) and a very small startup, the impact and amount of code I was able to ship and general contribution I was able to make was orders of magnitude larger at the small startup. I do think however that my experience at Nvidia opened many doors for me in terms of research opportunities and callbacks, so if you are a sophomore and haven't had any prior work experience that is also something to keep in mind.
can you be more specific on what you're having trouble deciding between? is it the salary/hourly rate? the team you'll be on? the type of work? the size of the company?

history.content: How about asking one of the faculty? They work closely with industry, so they might have an interesting opinion to offer.

children.subject:
re: impact

on the other hand, when I interned at a large, well-known company (but not faang), it took MONTHS for my code to get shipped, so keep in mind that they also don't "need" your work as much, whereas when I was at startups (both 5-10 employees and 1000 employees) my code went live all the time. 

though, one benefit of larger companies is that they're more likely to have a structured intern program with lots of intern-specific events, whereas at smaller companies it's less structured and more on you to reach out to meet others.

tl;dr - if you're younger, intern somewhere big first if you have that opportunity available to you and then go to a smaller place for later internships/full-time. Maximize learning and growth before focusing on impact because you have to know enough and have enough experience to make meaningful impact in the first place.

--

If you're younger or just starting out, don't discount the benefits of having had a big name under your past work experience. It's a lot easier to go from a FAANG company to a smaller place than the other way around because that "stamp of approval" gives you an implicit assumption of competence and can help you have more leverage down the road; guess it's not that different from the choice between going to Berkeley vs a smaller less well-known college. 

re: where you'll have the most impact, that depends on how you define it. TBH intern impact is pretty limited to begin with regardless of company because you're learning and are only there for a short amount of time... but do you define impact as reaching a lot of users and having heavy reach outside of your company? FAANG+ is 100% the way to go, where even the smallest button built by an intern reaches millions of people. (I shipped code on my third day of work that immediately went live on 40M user accounts; can't think of any non FAANG/unicorn companies where that would have been the case). If you're defining impact by how much of the team is affected by your work output, the smaller companies win here but again, remember that you're there for 12-16 weeks max and for most full-timers, that's still considered noob ramp up time.

Things like team placement process matter a lot for full-time placement, but don't get too hung up on it for an internship. Even in the worst case scenario (no control, crap team placement), chances are the FAANG company has enough resources that you'll learn a lot and get a strong experience regardless. Big companies are very much input in = output out; you can take advantage of intern mentorship programs and team networking and shadowing opportunities and all the other random intern-only activities. Whereas at a smaller company the limited resource pool actually gives you less control over your overall experience (counterintuitive, I know).

Of course, all of this is relative. If you're defining small company purely based on size and this is like, Airbnb vs Google they won't be that different from an intern perspective. This is more applicable to companies at different stages (ie. startup smaller than Series D vs FAANG/unicorn)

history.content: I'm deciding between two internships for next summer and not really sure which to take. Does anyone know of a Cal resource where I can talk to someone with a little insight on industry and where to start a software engineering career? I tried talking to an engineering advisor in the career center but they didn't have much to say in regards to picking between companies, more just general advice (which was also appreciated)
history.subject: Resource for picking internships?
